content: How to run a full node (Nitro)?
name: Running Full Node (Nitro)

steps.content:
The following hardware and software are required to run a full node:

### Minimum Hardware Configurations
The bare minimum hardware setup demands 8-16 GB of RAM and a 2-4 core CPU, akin to AWS's t3 xLarge instance. A crucial aspect is the storage, with at least 1.2TB of SSD capacity required, and it's important that this storage can be expanded as the Nitro blockchain is projected to swell by approximately 3GB daily. Keep in mind that as the blockchain expands, these minimum storage specifications will rise, so opting for hardware exceeding these minimums is advisable for maintaining a resilient full node.

### Prerequisites 
The recommended practice is to employ the latest Docker image specified by `offchainlabs/nitro-node:v2.1.1-e9d8842`. For the Arbitrum One network, it is essential to begin with a database snapshot, which establishes the historical state of the blockchain. This snapshot can be integrated via the ``--init.url`` parameter on the node's first run, where an example snapshot might be located at `https://snapshot.arbitrum.foundation/arb1/nitro-pruned.tar`. This local snapshot can be referenced by using the `--init.url` parameter with a file URI scheme, such as ``--init.url="file:///path/to/snapshot/in/container/snapshot-file.tar"``. 

### Required Parameters
When configuring a Nitro full node, the `--parent-chain.connection.url` parameter is used to link the node with a Layer 1 Ethereum node's RPC URL, which can be either self-hosted or provided by a third party. For identifying the Layer 2 chain, `--chain.id` or `--chain.name` parameters are used to specify the chain by its ID or name respectively, with the latter being a newer option introduced in version v2.1.0, replacing the previous `--l1.url` and `--l2.chain-id` parameters.

### Important Ports
Configuring a Nitro node requires setting up specific ports: 8547 for RPC services, 9642 for Sequencer Feed, and 8548 for WebSocket connections. To enable the WebSocket port, use flags `--ws.port=8548`, `--ws.addr=0.0.0.0` to bind to all interfaces, and `--ws.origins=*` to allow all origins.

steps.content:
### Putting it Together 
When setting up a Nitro node via Docker, itâ€™s essential to mount an external volume to `/home/user/.arbitrum` in the container for persistent database storage. First, ensure the local directory (e.g., `/some/local/dir/arbitrum`) exists to prevent permission issues. Run the node with the following command: 
`docker run --rm -it -v /some/local/dir/arbitrum:/home/user/.arbitrum -p 0.0.0.0:8547:8547 -p 0.0.0.0:8548:8548 offchainlabs/nitro-node:v2.1.1-e9d8842 --parent-chain.connection.url https://l1-node:8545 --chain.id=<L2ChainId> --http.api=net,web3,eth,debug --http.corsdomain=* --http.addr=0.0.0.0 --http.vhosts=*`
If your L1 node is on the same machine (`localhost`), add `--network host` for proper networking. Use this command for a smooth shutdown that preserves the current state and provides a 300-second timeout to save the state:
`docker stop --time=300 $(docker ps -aq)`
